results.notes:
Found these growing in the garden amongst some leafy groundcover. I think that these begin with a thin veil and white gills that darken to a brownish color as the mushroom ages. These mushrooms were found together in the same patch.

Don’t know if this is of any identification value, but when I picked a young example of this mushroom, they’ll was just dissipating, a bunch of small gnat-like organisms flew out. Whatever they are, they are clearly of interest to this particular type of flying insect.

results.notes:
Three fruiting bodies along the roots of mature Quercus sp.(likely non-native red Oak).
Long rooting hypogeous stem with wrinkled folds tapering downward(attached to roots of Quercus).
Staining immediately pinkish/red where handled.
Smooth Peridium(above ground portion) slightly splitting on two specimens on right.
Peridium NOT PIMPLED.
KOH on Peridium: reddish brown/orange after a few seconds. See at home images of KOH application.
Peridium is very thick walled/firm. See bisection shots included.
Gleba: brownish purple.
Gleba KOH: stains reddish brown/Orange similar to Peridium reaction but a bit more orange. Changing to blue/green after full dehydration. See images included of application.
Harvested all 3 specimens.
Sliced off a small portion of mature Gleba tissue and performed crush mount in KOH.
Spores: round, medium/large. Reticulate.
Captured Multiple shots of Cystidia like ornamentation and long hyphal threads at both 100X and 400X magnification using my celestron digital scope.
Thoroughly dehydrated all 3 specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes: Morphology: globular cap with wrinkled highly-incurved irregularly undulating margin; gills dark brown with white edge, sinuate with adnate attachment; white shimmery striated (twisted-fibrous) stem stains golden-gray. Spore print: chestnut- benzo brown. Spores: ellipsoid-ovate, rarely near amygdaliform [N=14] (13.6)14.1-16.5(16.9) × (7.6)7.9-9.8(10.9) μm [Me = 15.3 × 8.9 μm]; Q = (1.5)1.6-1.87(1.9) [Qe = 1.7]. Measurements: [n=3] cap 6.9-8.9 mm across by 5.9-6.3 high, stem 1.6-3.1 thick (widest adjacent to cap) by 44.6-54.5 tall. Growth pattern: gregarious. Habitat: mowed grass at outer edge of baseball field nearby Panaeolus foenisecii.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection made by an unknown foray participant. I though this was some albino sect. Vaginatae, but then I look a bit more closely and realized this was a sect. Amidella. This is the second time I almost make this kind of mistake at Horseshoe Bend; the first time was in 2018, obs 323941.
This is either A. dolichopus or a slender A. whetstoneae, like the above post from 5 years ago.
I meant to save this collection, but it was discarded during the hasty post ID clean-up before I remembered about it.

Description: Found inside a hollow stump.
Cap is grey with shades of green and hints of rust color.
Does not bruse easy but takes hours to show light grey stain on the cap but rust color on the style. Has pores instead of gills. Bone white inside. Stype has a net like design.
Appears to be in the Boletes family but grows in a cluster of 3 or 4 attached at the base.
Smells like you think a mushroom should smell when cooking. Very earthy.
What is its ID.

results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection made by unknown participants.
Two immature but large and robust fruiting bodies presumably of the same species apparently found separately by different collectors. The colors are accurate: the caps are distinctly brown. Also note the long brown fibrils on the stipes of both fruitbodies and the large volval patch on the cap and the grayish partial veil of the second mushroom.
Possible IDs include A. spreta and A. murrilliana. The morphological concept of the former species ranges widely in terms of the size of basidiomata and cap color.
This preserved collection will be sampled for DNA.

results.notes: These always seem to grow within close proximity Panaeolous or at least within fields where I’ve seen Panaeolous at other times. Last year I noticed that these would pop up first, then they’d grow concurrent with Panaeolous and eventually there’d be more and more Panaeolous with a seemingly correlated drop in Panaeolopsis. Most will have black gills with white edges but occasionally I find some that have caramel colored gills which I suspect might be “sterile” fruiting bodies. Bottoms of the stipes sometimes bruise blue to varying degree. They seem to more readily separate from the lawn/soil in comparison to Panaeolous specimens growing with them and also have a tendency to bring some mycelium and colonized lawn bits with them. I’ve also included pictures of the Panaeolous that were growing in the same lawn patch with

results.notes: Morphology: cap broadly-convex to plane-upturned often campanulate, occasionally with slight umbo (sometimes parabolic or conical) deep caramel (orange-brown) when fresh fading to pale yellowish-beige when dry (typically with grayish outer margin where moist) often striated and circular from above; pale pinkish sub-decurrent gills narrowly-spaced, sometimes rather wavy; whitish twisted striated stem unevenly stains reddish-brown to grayish-black, quite malleable. Spore print: dark purplish-brown. Spores: ovate, ellipsoid often citriniform or globose, tending towards amygdaloid (rarely nearing rhomboid), translucent [N=50] measure (6.1)6.4 – 8(8.5) × (3.8)4 – 4.8(5.5) µm [Me = 7.2 × 4.4 µm]; Q = (1.3)1.4 – 1.8(1.9) [Qe = 1.6]. Measurements: [n=12] 8.1-22.0 (avg. 14.24) mm across by 0.75-6.1 (avg. 2.39) high, stem 1.0-2.1 (avg. 1.67) thick by 15.0-36.4 (avg. 23.69) tall. Growth pattern: scattered to gregarious, rarely approaching caespitose. Habitat: woodlot trailside nearing swamp on dried leaves (typically red oak and sugar maple), stick fragments or wood-chip edges.

results.notes: Morphology: globular to broadly-hemispheric cap with highly-incurved (rather irregularly folded crenate) wavy wrinkled striated margin, stains blackish-brown; black gills; bright white shimmery stem stains yellowish-gray, hollow falling apart into strips, rather malleable. Spore print: jet black. Spores: broadly-ovate (often nearing obovate) to ellipsoid, very dark brown nearing black [N=29] measure (10.7)11.3 – 13.4(13.5) × (6.5)6.8 – 8.3(8.7) µm [Me = 12.6 × 7.6 µm]; Q = (1.4)1.5 – 1.8 [Qe = 1.7]. Measurements: [n=4] cap 9.1-30.7 mm across by 9.9-11.3 high, stem 3.1-4.1 thick (tapering towards cap) by 23.1-65.7 tall. Growth pattern: gregarious. Habitat: woodlot trailside approaching swamp.

results.notes:
Ecology:

Found on run next to path near GVSU campus, growing near hardwood, no conifer spotted. Gregarious. thick short and stocky.

Macroscopic Features:

Cap 9-12 cm in diameter. Thick, surface very very velvety and soft. Brownish reddish, some spots more red than others, with the center dark greyish black. Where the dark is it isnt soft. Bruises dark.

Pore surface yellowish to orangish to orange-red in older specimens, bruises dark blue fast.

Stipe 3-3.5 cm long, 5.2-5.4 cm wide. Yellow at top, red towards bottom. Whole stipe covered in reticulation, matches stipe color except some red reticulation over yellow towards top, bruises blue. Has large thick “root” out of bottom of stipe, not sure what to call it.

Flesh white, except for red in base of stipe, bruises blue almost instantly. Red slowly turns black. All flesh then eventually fading to light grayish with some light blue remaining.

Smell indistinct, taste indistinct.

Spore print Olive green/brown

Macrochemical Tests:

KOH instantly dark reddish on cap surface, yellowish on flesh. NH4OH negative on cap surface.

Microscopic Characteristics:

Spore Size: 11.0-13.4 μm x 4.9-6.1 μm, N=24, Q = 1.9-2.3, Me = 12.0 μm x 5.7 μm, Qe = 2.1

Spores in pictures shown at 1000x magnification, mounted in H20

results.notes: Morphology: broadly-convex to wavy-upturned (sometimes slightly umbonate) cap reddish when fresh becoming auburn-brown then cream-buff (often with dark brown marginal ring) when dry; gills sub-decurrent, rather closely-spaced, pale brown to auburn; malleable whitish orange-brown stem progressively more blackish-mahogany towards base. results.notes:
6” long 1-1/2” wide very white scaly un-ringed tapering stalk with 1” blueish ball shaped smooth cap. Stem is larger at base. Stem and cap grew horizontal to earth and appeared to have 90 degree bend immediately after emerging. Phallic in appearance. Have never seen anything like it. It has not shown reproductive method yet and seems immature so no way to print or identify a ring yet.

Second specimen shows 90degree bend at 1” height. And exhibits blue tipped “notched” scales and only slightly blue hues cap.

Neither demonstrated mycelium or primordial above ground. Both specimen are growing under mature red oaks and a white oak is within 100’.

results.notes:
Collection and the two first field pictures by Krista Willmorth.
What attracted our attention to this Russula was the striking orange/yellow gills.
Under mix conifers, fir and spruce present.
Cap 4.5 cm., incurved, depressed, viscid, pale grey-green with some violet around the margin.
Stem 3.8 × 2 cm., white, inside a little chambered.
Taste mild, not perceptible odor.
Chemicals: KOH pallid yellow/orange, on cap. Feso4 pink on stipe.
Spore print: IV d, on the Romagnesi scale.
Spores: Subglobose, B3 on the Woo scale, isolated or with few connections, warts approximately 1.0 μ.
Spores (8.5 -9.8) x (7.5 – 8.6); on Aver. (9.1 × 8.2), Q = 1.11.
Basidia (50 -60) x (12.2-13.5).
Cystidia (66-72) x (8.4-10.2) fusiform with an apical appendage.
Pileus with clavate to capitate hairs, sometimes branched, and septate, perhaps with encrusted hyphae 3.0-6.0 μ. that is hard to see without the proper chemicals. Pileocystidia, not seen.

results.notes: A very small fungi found on a large very rotten tree felled in Hurricane Sandy. The cap = .8 cm. darker than the photo which was taken several hours later. The gills were redder than the photo, almost subdeccurent. The stipe was red under the gills fading to a yellow hue towards the base. Surprisingly tough for its size. I was unable to take a picture in situ due to the cat brier, and darkness caused by vegetation, also my boots were sinking in the black muck. There were no conifers in the area. I did not get a spore print. I will send it out for DNA analysis since it seems fairly unusual.

results.notes:
Growing on the bark of a Tsuga canadensis stick submerged in a fast-running rocky stream. Basidiocarps pendent, smooth and white. All structures inamyloid. Marginal hairs coralloid, thin, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Basidia 2-sterigmate. Spores hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.9) 5.2 – 6.3 (6.5) × (4.3) 4.6 – 5.6 (5.9) µm; Q = 1 – 1.18 (1.2); N = 30; Me = 5.7 × 5.2 µm; Qe = 1.1

results.notes: In seasonally dry coastal forest on living Bourreria succulenta. Perennial, new hymenia growing sporadically on old tissue giving it a canker-like aspect. Pores 6-8/mm, black line in context below tomentum. Spores pigmented with a slight thickened wall, dissepiment hyphae cylindrical with thickening walls and occasional constrictions along length, lightly encrusted. Tube trama with scattered, large, rhomboid crystals much like the illustration of Phylloporia crystallina in Zhou et. al. (2022).

results.notes: Terrestrial on forest floor, but not immediately nearby any known EM hosts in the Polygonaceae/Nyctaginaceae. Nearby plants included: Guazuma ulmifolia, Melicoccus bijugatus (introduced), Goetzea elegans (planted), Ficus (citrifolia?), and Randia aculeata. The only known EM hosts were a small seedling of Guapira fragrans and a Pisonia aculeata vine at some distance.
results.location_name: ANP Cuevas el Convento, Guyanilla, Puerto Rico, USA

results.notes: Variable in aspect, these were collected as potentially three different species because of the presence/absence of cream colored surface squamules and the presence of both clavate cylindrical and filiform stroma, but on closer inspection they appear to be conspecific, with the same spore shape, size, and germ slit length/orientation. This is also supported by the fact that they were fruiting together on the same piece of wood. The variable stroma morphology is probably what Dennis (1956) discusses as the differences between X. curta and X. feejeensis.
results.location_name: ANP Cuevas el Convento, Guyanilla, Puerto Rico, USA

results.notes: The largest Xylaria fruiting bodies I have seen, with a 25 cm stroma length. They were apparently fruiting from decaying roots of a large, dead Ceiba pentandra tree. These are very similar in stromal texture and spore size/morphology to X. kegeliana, except for the absence of a germ slit that spirals (straight to slightly oblique in this collection)
results.location_name: ANP Cuevas el Convento, Guyanilla, Puerto Rico, USA

results.notes: Appearing terrestrial (probably from buried woody debris), lamellae becoming clay pinkish when dry. Epithelial pileipellis (micro photo of cells), spores subglobose with oily contents, hymenial cystidia present, thin walled, metuloidal cystidia absent.
